item.title: 8 Best Pixel Art First-Person Shooters
item.description:
The first-person shooter is among the most saturated video game genres in the modern day, recently enjoying a resurgence in the boomer shooter subgenre. This sub-genre is particularly notable for its use of pixelated textures and 2D, pixel-art sprites.

While not all first-person shooters in this niche make use of 2D characters in 3D environments, many of them do. These are just a few excellent examples of modern shooters with an old-school, pixelated look.

8 Fashion Police Squad

An Old-School Arena Shooter Without The Gore

  • Platform(s): PC, Xbox, PlayStation, Nintendo Switch
  • Released: 2022
  • Developer(s): Mopeful Games
  • Genre: FPS

This old-school arena shooter features a rich and vibrant pixel-art style, with 2D directional sprites for its various enemies and an arsenal of pixelated weaponry. Fashion Police Squad , if its name didn't give it away already, takes a humorous approach to its theme, setting, and light narrative. This, along with the lack of gore, allows it to stand out in an increasingly saturated genre.

Fashion Police Squad isn't the most complex or expansive entry in the resurgence of boomer shooters, but it provides a light-hearted experience with fluid movement controls and vibrant art direction. For fans of retro-styled arena shooters that don't mind the tongue-in-cheek tone and theme, Fashion Police Squad is worth a shot.

7 Project Warlock

A Combination Of Stylized Art And Expressive Battle Arenas

Project Warlock 's enemies, weapons, and environments are all visualized with well-crafted pixel-art. Like many of the games it takes inspiration from, Project Warlock features 2D characters and props in 3D environments, allowing for a combination of stylized art and expressive battle arenas.

Thankfully, Project Warlock's visuals are given plenty of time to shine in the game's wide variety of distinct environments. The frequent changes in setting also ensure the game rarely gets stale, keeping things fresh from beginning to end.

6 Post Void

Psychedelic Action At A Breakneck Pace

This psychedelic action roguelike has players speeding through various rooms and corridors at a breakneck pace, taking out enemies as fast as they can on their way to the exit. To be successful, players must blast their way through each zone before the liquid in their idol runs out, representing a constantly-draining health bar.

Post Void 's frantic, chaotic gameplay is only matched by its psychedelic, pixel-art style. 2D, pixelated sprites represent the various unhinged enemies in the game, as well as the player's skinny arms and arsenal of snappy guns. The environments are painted in pixelated textures, featuring a vast array of bright colors that can frequently be disorientating.

5 Prodeus

A Heavily DOOM-Inspired Retro FPS

This gory, heavily DOOM -inspired old-school FPS is packed with punchy gunfights and a low-resolution, pixelated art-style. Prodeus is incredibly old-school, despite its recent release, and follows the same formula of 90s shooters, tasking players with gunning down enemies to acquire color-coded keys.

Prodeus' 2D, pixelated enemies are plentiful, giving players plenty of reasons to use their arsenal of old-school weaponry. Furthermore, despite the environments using a variety of pixelated textures, atmospheric lighting prevents the screen from getting too messy.

4 Fortune's Run

A Combination Of Tactical Stealth And Fast-Paced Action

Fortune's Run is a strange game that's slow to start, but players that are patient with its slower pace will find a truly distinctive experience that offers a combination of tactical stealth and fast-paced action gameplay. The slower pace of the game, in comparison to other boomer-shooters, can likely be attributed to the game's implementation of immersive-sim elements.

Fortune's Run features expansive, industrial science fiction environments that are packed with pixelated detail. Furthermore, the game's character sprites, portraits, and weapons are all visualized in crunchy pixel art and pixelated textures.

3 Ion Fury

A Love Letter To Build Engine Games

Developed in the classic Build Engine (the very same engine used to make iconic shooters such as Duke Nukem 3D and Blood ), Ion Fury is an inherently retro-styled first-person shooter. As a result, it's no surprise that its visuals are packed with pixelated sprites and textures.

While it's by no means a carbon copy of the games it's inspired by, the Duke Nukem , Shadow Warrior , and Blood influences are apparent from the get-go in Ion Fury . From the fun but somewhat limited arsenal of weapons, to the game's approach to level design and plethora of secrets, Ion Fury is a retro shooter through-and-through, with a pixelized aesthetic to boot.

2 Warhammer 40,000: Boltgun

A High-Octane Gore-Fest In The World Of 40k

This high-octane gore-fest is a fast-paced boomer shooter that puts players in the hulking shoes of an Ultramarine. Warhammer 40k: Boltgun features a variety of pixelized 2D sprites for both its enemies and the player's FPS rig.

As with all boomer shooters, Boltgun takes a great deal of inspiration from classic 90s shooters, both in its visuals and its gameplay. However, the faithfully recreated Warhammer 40k setting, excessive gore, and a chainsword allow Boltgun to stand out among the crowd.

1 CULTIC

A Blood-Inspired FPS That Pays Homage To Resident Evil 4

Taking several pages out of Blood's book is CULTIC , a faithfully constructed retro shooter with horror elements inspired by Resident Evil 4 . CULTIC features the freedom of movement that fans of 90s shooters have come to expect over the years, though CULTIC's movement arguably feels more advanced than its influences.

CULTIC's gameplay is non-stop, action-packed fun with a dense atmosphere. This atmosphere is facilitated by strong art direction and an old-school approach to sound design and music. Sound effects are crunchy, matching the pixelated visual style perfectly. 2D sprites represent the player's FPS rig, as well as directional 2D sprites for the enemies, with a wide array of pixelated textures for the 3D environments that players explore throughout the game.

item.title: Bitlife: How to Complete The Golden Gals Challenge
item.description:
Bitlife is a fun simulation game in which players can create characters and completely control their lives. The devs introduce regular challenges to keep the game fresh and exciting. This week, we have a new challenge called Golden Gals, which will run for four days. Read on to find out how to Golden Gals Challenge in Bitlife .

How to Complete the Golden Gals Challenge in Bitlife

The Bitlife Golden Gals Challenge has five parts:

  • Be born a female in Miami
  • Work as a teacher for 20+ years
  • Get a divorce
  • Make 3 female friends at the age of 55+
  • Date a clown at age 55+.

How to Be Born a Female in Miami in Bitlife

First, you will have to be born a female in Miami. This step is pretty simple. All the players have to do is start a new life, select female as your characterâ€™s gender, choose the USA as their country and Miami as their birthplace.

Work As a Teacher for 20+ Years

Now you will need to work as a school teacher for more than 20 years. For this purpose, age up to 18 and apply for a university. Choose a degree and study hard for the next four years until graduation. Then go to â€˜Occupationâ€™, click on â€˜Jobsâ€™, and interview for the â€˜School Teacherâ€™ job. Once you get the job, keep working for 20 years.

How to Get a Divorce in Bitlife

To get a divorce in Bitlife , players will need to get married first. If you haven't married yet, you can find a date by going to â€˜Activitiesâ€™, selecting â€˜Loveâ€™, and then selecting the Date option.

Once you are married, stay together for some time and then divorce your partner by going to 'Relationships' and selecting the 'Spouse' and 'Divorce' options.

How to Make 3 Female Friends at the Age of 55+ in Bitlife

To complete this step, players need to be 55 years old. So age up until your character is 55 y/o and then make three female friends. Bitizens can also befriend their coworkers for this step. For that, go to the â€˜Occupationâ€™ section, click â€˜School Teacherâ€™, click on â€˜Co-workersâ€™, and choose three people.

How to Date a Clown at Age 55+ in Bitlife

Lastly, gamers will have to date a clown. To do this, you can find a date from the dating app found in the â€˜Loveâ€™ section under Activities. However, it can take some time to find a partner who works as a clown. Players can also apply for a job at a circus and date a coworker.

item.title: Alan Wake 2: Every Trophy/Achievement (& How to Unlock Them)
item.description:
Achievements (or Trophies on PlayStation platforms) have become commonplace since they first made their debut on the Xbox 360. While many players do not care for achievements/trophies, just as many players go out of their way to get every single achievement or trophy in a game. Obtaining achievements/trophies will vary in difficulty across all games, and in some cases, players will not have to 100% the game to get every achievement.

Alan Wake 2 is a fairly easy game to get all the achievements/trophies in, especially since there are no achievements associated with difficulty. That said, there are plenty of collectibles that are easy to miss that will result in needing to do another playthrough. There are 66 achievements (or 67 for PlayStation because of the platinum trophy) in total for Alan Wake 2 , and here is how to get them.

Updated June 9, 2024 by Paul Woodward: With the release of the first DLC for Alan Wake 2 , there are 12 new achievements/trophies for players to unlock. While it won't take a lot of time for players to unlock them all, Night Springs is certainly a DLC that longtime fans of the Alan Wake series will enjoy. When Lake House is released, the achievements/trophies part of that DLC will be added as well.

All Achievements/Trophies in Alan Wake 2

Achievement/Trophy Name

How to Unlock

Escape its Gravity

If players happen to get grabbed by an enemy, they can escape by using a Hand Flare if they have one in their inventory. There will be a button prompt on the screen to use the Hand Flare.

This is the Moment

While dodging attacks is fairly easy, the tricky part of this achievement/trophy is that it has to be done at the last possible second. If done correctly, time will (briefly) slow down and the achievement/trophy will unlock.

Not the Last

Unlocks upon picking up the first page of the manuscript. Since this is part of the story, it cannot be missed.

Shining in the Night

When enemies are approaching, activate a Hand Flare. Not only will they move away from players, but this will also unlock the achievement/trophy.

Secret Stashes

Unlocked by simply opening one Cult Stash and one Lunch Box. Both of these items can be found all over the place, especially if players take time to explore every corner of the map. These only appear in Saga's chapters.

Finding a Way

This is unlocked during Return 3: Local Girl. Since finding the screwdriver is a mandatory objective, this cannot be missed.

Cut Short

Unlocked as part of the story during Return 5: Old Gods. Since the Boltcutters are needed to advance the story, this cannot be missed either.

Chase the Source

When the darkness shield is burned away on a Taken, there will be a glowing red point somewhere on their body. Shooting this not only causes massive damage to the enemy but also unlocks this achievement/trophy.

Darkness Coiled

All players have to do to unlock this is focus the flashlight on an enemy to remove their shield.

Strange Reality

Throughout Saga's chapters, players will encounter dolls that can be picked up and placed on diagrams. There will be a paper nearby that gives a hint for what dolls go where. If done correctly, a Charm will spawn nearby. Players need to solve five of these puzzles to unlock this achievement/trophy.

The Koskela Brothers

In order to unlock this, players will need to watch every single TV commercial in Saga's chapters.

The Trail of the Writer

Just like the achievement/trophy above, this one can be unlocked by watching every TV scene that occurs during Alan's chapters.

Bring It

This can be unlocked by obtaining the Sawed-Off Shotgun in Return 2: The Heart.

Ready for a Fight

Unlocked by acquiring the Hunting Rifle in Return 5: Old Gods.

Greatest Hits

Unlocked in Return 3: Local Girl by obtaining the Crossbow from a Cult Stash.

Stop Right There

This achievement/trophy can be unlocked by acquiring the Pump-Action Shotgun in Return 6: Scratch.

Find the Light

Unlocked as part of the story between Initiation 1: Late Night and Initiation 2: Casey.

Lights Shining

This achievement/trophy is unmissable, as it is part of the musical chapter in Alan's story.

Yippee Ki-yay

Can be unlocked by finding and acquiring the Double-Barrelled Shotgun in the Oceanview Hotel bar. Once in the bar, use the Angel Lamp.

Aimed Ahead

Kill five enemies with headshots. Progress is saved, so players do not need to kill five enemies at once.

Coffee Thermos

This cannot be missed, as unlocking a save point room is part of the story.

Felt Good

Use any healing item. It doesn't matter what kind.

Lawman

Defeat Nightingale, the boss of Return 2: The Heart.

Bright Falls' Finest

Defeat both Mulligan and Thornton during Return 3: Local Girl.

Girl in Love

Defeat Cynthia in Return 5: Old Gods.

Filled with Rage

Defeat Scratch in Return 6: Scratch.

Storm Cloud

Successfully escape from the Dark Presence during Initiation 2: Casey. This is mandatory, so it cannot be missed.

Stop the Monster

This is unlocked by focusing the flashlight on a Taken Thrower just before they are about to teleport. This variant of Taken teleports around a lot, so players will either have to get familiar with their attack and teleport patterns or unlock this through luck.

Growing Stronger

Unlocked by upgrading one of Saga's weapons once. This is done by finding scattered manuscript fragments and spending them on upgrades in the Mind Place.

All Smiles

Upgrade one of Saga's weapons completely, which means getting all the upgrades that are available for one weapon. The easiest way to unlock this is to focus on one weapon to upgrade, especially since there won't be enough scattered manuscript fragments to upgrade every weapon.

Carry his Words

Find and unlock one Word of Power while in the Dark Place. While these are easily missable, players only need to find one to unlock the achievement/trophy.

Nightmare Territory

Pick up any map that is found throughout the game. The location of one is called out to players during Return 1: Invitation.

Grew Bigger

This can be unlocked by upgrading inventory size once.

I'll Find You

This can be unlocked by finding every single doll that is part of the Nursey Rhyme puzzles.

Stunning Vistas

This achievement/trophy can easily be unlocked by tossing a Flashbang grenade at the feet of an enemy.

Gone for Good

Take a Propane Canister and throw it at the feet of a Taken and then shoot the canister to cause an explosion.

The Story Come True

Beat Alan Wake 2 . This will unlock as the credits roll.

Hunting Season

Complete the prologue, Return 0: The Cult.

Somebody's Home

Complete Return 1: Invitation

Into the Overlap

Complete Return 2: The Heart

Back in Watery

Complete Return 3: Local Girl

We Watch in the Night

Complete Return 4: No Chance

The Old Gods

Complete Return 5: Old Gods

Seeing Double

Complete Return 6: Scratch

Rock n' Roll, Baby

Complete Return 7: Summoning

The Final Deerfest

Complete Return 8: Deerfest

End of the Road

Complete Return 9: Come Home

Talk Show

Complete Initiation 1: Late Night

New York City

Complete Initiation 2: Casey

Return

Complete Initiation 3: Haunting

All His Life

Complete Initiation 4: We Sing

In a Fancy Hotel

Complete Initiation 5: Room 665

Told and Retold

Complete Initiation 6: Return

Behind the Masks

Complete Initiation 7: Masks

The Cult of the Word

Complete Initiation 8: Zane's Film

His Way Out

Complete Initiation 9: Gone

All Accounted For

Find all weapons for both Saga and Alan.

In One Go

To unlock this trophy/achievement, players simply have to kill an enemy in one shot with the Crossbow. Make sure to remove their darkness shield first and then aim for the head.

Shift in Reality

Unlocked by completing every Nursery Rhyme puzzle.

Hidden by the Trees

Unlocked by finding every Lunch Box and Cult Stash in the game.

Coffee-Themed Fun

Shoot the cardboard cutout of a bear in Coffee World. The cardboard cutout will be to the left of a sign that points to the left for The Percolator and points to the right for The Espresso Express and Fresh Pot Gift Shop.

Filling the Shape

In order to unlock this trophy/achievement, place a charm on every slot of Saga's charm bracelet. There are only three, and if players are doing the Nursery Rhyme puzzles they will have plenty of charms.

Rustic Charm

This achievement/trophy can be unlocked by finding every charm in the game. These only appear during Saga's chapters, so don't look for them while playing as Alan.

Back to Life

In order to unlock this achievement/trophy, all players have to do is have a Coffee Mug Charm equipped and then take fatal damage from any enemy or boss. The Coffee Mug Charm will bring players back to life.

The Nice Things in Life

This is unlocked by petting the dog who appears in Suomi Hall in Downtown Watery at the end of Return 5: Old Gods.

The Other Side

This achievement/trophy is easily unlocked by using the dark puddle in a save point room to switch between either Saga or Alan.

Since the platinum trophy simply requires unlocking all other trophies, it has not been included in the table above. Listed below are the achievements/trophies for Night Springs.

Night Springs Achievements/Trophies

Achievement/Trophy Name

How to Unlock

Accessorize!

Take the accessories from the kitchen.

Hot Biscuits!

Defeat three enemies at once with any kind of explosive.

I Could Listen to Him All Day

Listen to all the Writer's messages.

Love Always Wins!

Complete Number One Fan

Smooth Blend

Enter the warehouse office without getting caught by the coffee mascots during Episode 2.

Dark as the Void

Solve the coffee roasting temperature puzzle.

Percolate

Solve all the stashes.

You Are Coffee

Complete North Star.

This Page Here

Read the pages on the floor in the Green Room

Retro

Complete the arcade reality

Ride the Vortex

Travel to a different reality by using a TV

Multiversal Agent

Complete Time Breaker

item.title: Destiny 2: The Final Shape's Prismatic Progression Is a Double-Edged Sword
item.description:
Highlights

  • Destiny 2's Prismatic subclass in The Final Shape allows players to combine Light and Darkness powers for a unique Guardian build.
  • Players must explore to find Prismatic Fragments throughout the campaign, unlocking them in chests after tough battles.
  • It's possible to finish the campaign without all Fragments, making the subclass unreliable until all pieces are collected.

Destiny 2 's new Prismatic subclass is undoubtedly one of the best features of the latest expansion, The Final Shape. With it, players can wield the powers of both the Light and the Darkness, using a unique combination of abilities from every subclass they've learned up to this point. Similarly to Dragon's Dogma 2 's Warfarer vocation, Destiny 2 's Prismatic subclass allows players to build a powerhouse of a Guardian, and these builds can grow even more powerful with the addition of the game's new Exotic class items. However, to unlock the Prismatic subclass, players will first need to play The Final Shape's campaign, which sees them acquiring the subclass fairly early on.

Although players can unlock the new Prismatic subclass not too far into The Final Shape's campaign, they won't unlock every Prismatic Fragment automatically. Instead, they must venture off the beaten path many times throughout the campaign to find the missing Fragments and flesh out their Prismatic build. This is a new form of subclass progression for Destiny 2 , and it's already not a popular one. That being said, there is an undeniable benefit to it, even if the whole system initially seems to be a bit of a pain.

The Pros and Cons of Destiny 2: The Final Shape's Prismatic Progression System

The Final Shape's Prismatic Progression System Encourages Thorough Exploration

In The Final Shape, the subclass progression system is much different from what it has been before. In Lightfall, the expansion before The Final Shape, players could unlock Fragments for their Strand subclass by earning Strand Meditations and spending them at the Pouka Pond. For Destiny 2 's normal subclasses â€” Void, Solar, and Arc â€” players can visit Ikora Rey in the Tower and unlock those Fragments there. This is a very dependable system, as it simply requires players to obtain the resources necessary for purchasing the Fragments and then spend them on whichever Fragments they wish to unlock. Unlike Destiny 2 's other subclasses, the Final Shape's Prismatic Fragments require a bit of exploring.

As players progress through The Final Shape's campaign, they will regularly come across opportunities to obtain more Fragments for their Prismatic subclass in special chests. These are often found after challenging encounters and boss fights, but others can only be found by looking in the most unlikely places. One Prismatic Fragment, for instance, is hidden in a crashed plane on the mountain during the Ascent mission in The Final Shape. Hiding the Fragments like this encourages players to explore the Pale Heart a bit more than they might initially think they should, and since the Pale Heart is more than worth exploring, this part of the Prismatic progression system works. Unfortunately, there is a downside.

It's Possible to Finish The Final Shape's Campaign Without All the Prismatic Fragments

The biggest issue with The Final Shape's Prismatic progression system is that it's possible to make it through the expansion's campaign without all the Fragments for the Prismatic subclass. When players are first granted access to the Prismatic subclass during the campaign, it might feel exciting at first, but it quickly becomes noticeable just how unreliable it is without all of its Fragments unlocked. This makes the fact that it's possible to miss all the Fragments during a playthrough of the campaign a massive letdown, especially since it would mean playing through the campaign again. Furthermore, there is sometimes no indication of where the Fragments can be found, so players have to be extremely thorough, get lucky, or look their locations up online before venturing into the campaign.

Some of the Prismatic Facets in Destiny 2 cannot be unlocked during the campaign in any case, and players will have to wait further.

While there is certainly a benefit to The Final Shape requiring players to seek out the Fragments for their new Prismatic subclass, it's unfortunate that it's possible to make it to the end of the campaign without obtaining all of them. Perhaps Bungie will eventually alleviate this issue by making each Fragment more readily available, but for now, players may just have to face the music.

item.title: Helldivers 2: How to Raise the Flag
item.description:
Developed by Arrowhead Game Studios, Helldivers 2 is a popular third-person shooter game in which you team up with other players to fight deadly bugs and aliens on different planets. With its excellent graphics and fun mechanics, the game has impressed many gamers. Your main goal is to wipe out aliens and other hostile creatures and restore human dominance in the galaxy.

Missions are a big part of the Helldivers 2 gameplay. From the Terminid and Automaton missions to general ones, the game has many exciting tasks to keep you engaged. One of them is to raise the Super Earth flag. Itâ€™s an introductory mission with an easy difficulty level that aims to spread democracy on the planet. This guide will walk you through the steps of raising the flag in Helldivers 2 .

How to Raise the Flag in Helldivers 2

Raising the flag in Helldivers 2 is a simple but important step to announce your authority in the enemy base. It is available only on low difficulty levels, so even beginners can start this mission after completing the training.

First, you need to enter the objective area, which is marked by a purple circle on the map. So open the map and travel to the objective area. Once you're there, use the Super Earth Flag Stratagem to set up the flagpole and raise the flag in the enemy territory.

For those who donâ€™t know, Stratagems are special tools that you can summon during a mission to complete missions and deal with your enemies. The Super Earth Flag Stratagem is a mission-specific tool. To summon it, go to the Stratagem menu, where you will see the Super Earth Flag Stratagem option. Just click on it, and a flagpole will land.

Once the flag lands, you will be attacked by bugs. Use your best weapons to deal with them. While you do that, a timer will start, and the Super Earth flag will begin to rise. It will take almost two minutes for the flag to go all the way up.

After killing the enemies, wait for the flag to rise. And yes, make sure to stay around the flagpole, as the timer will stop if you move away and wonâ€™t start until you are back. While the flag rises, the anthem of Super Earth will play in the background to boost your spirits. After the timer ends, the mission will be completed, and you will get your rewards.
